name: Apple___Apple_scab
cause: Caused by the fungus Venturia inaequalis, thriving in cool and moist climates. Appears as dark lesions on leaves, reducing photosynthesis.
cure: Remove fallen leaves, prune to increase airflow, and apply preventive fungicides early in the growing season.

name: Apple___Black_rot
cause: Caused by Botryosphaeria obtusa, typically infects wounded or weak leaves and fruits during warm, humid conditions.
cure: Remove mummified fruit and infected twigs. Use fungicide sprays in early spring and maintain plant vigor.

name: Apple___Cedar_apple_rust
cause: Fungal disease (Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae) needing both junipers and apples to complete its life cycle. Shows orange spots on leaves.
cure: Eliminate nearby juniper trees, apply rust-targeting fungicides during bud break, and choose resistant varieties.

name: Apple___healthy
cause: No disease present. Leaves are green, well-formed, and show no lesions or spots.
cure: Continue regular pruning, proper irrigation, and fertilization to maintain optimal leaf health.

name: Blueberry___healthy
cause: Plant is free from disease; foliage appears lush, green, and uniformly shaped.
cure: Ensure good drainage, mulch properly, and monitor soil pH to sustain healthy leaf development.

name: Cherry___Powdery_mildew
cause: Caused by Podosphaera clandestina, leaves appear with white powdery patches, often in warm, dry climates.
cure: Prune dense canopies, avoid overhead watering, and apply sulfur-based fungicides during early stages.

name: Cherry___healthy
cause: No infections observed. Leaves are vibrant and undamaged.
cure: Keep trees spaced properly, maintain soil moisture, and inspect leaves regularly for early disease signs.

name: Corn___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray_leaf_spot
cause: Caused by Cercospora zeae-maydis. Brown-gray lesions appear on lower leaves and move upward.
cure: Use resistant hybrids, rotate crops, and apply fungicides at VT (tasseling) stage if symptoms are severe.

name: Corn___Common_rust
cause: Fungus Puccinia sorghi causes rust-colored pustules on leaves, reducing energy production.
cure: Plant resistant corn varieties and apply foliar fungicides at the first sign of infection.

name: Corn___Northern_Leaf_Blight
cause: Caused by Exserohilum turcicum, showing as cigar-shaped lesions on older leaves during humid weather.
cure: Use hybrid seeds with resistance, till crop residue, and apply fungicide during silking stage if needed.

name: Corn___healthy
cause: Healthy corn leaves are free from spots or lesions and have a glossy green appearance.
cure: Ensure balanced fertilization, weed control, and adequate watering for sustained health.

name: Grape___Black_rot
cause: Caused by Guignardia bidwellii. Lesions form on leaves followed by black shriveled fruit.
cure: Prune infected areas, apply fungicides during early shoot growth, and remove fallen debris.

name: Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles)
cause: Complex disease involving several fungi. Leaves show tiger-striping and can die prematurely.
cure: Remove infected trunks or canes, prevent trunk injuries, and apply protective fungicide pastes.

name: Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spot)
cause: Caused by Pseudocercospora vitis. Brown angular lesions form along the leaf margins.
cure: Promote airflow by training vines, apply systemic fungicides, and maintain vineyard hygiene.

name: Grape___healthy
cause: No leaf damage detected. Growth is strong and green.
cure: Keep proper spacing, maintain soil fertility, and monitor regularly for mildew or rot.

name: Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening)
cause: Caused by Candidatus Liberibacter spp., transmitted by psyllid insects. Leaves appear blotchy and yellow.
cure: Control psyllids with insecticides, remove infected trees promptly, and use certified disease-free saplings.

name: Peach___Bacterial_spot
cause: Caused by Xanthomonas campestris pv. pruni. Dark, water-soaked spots appear on leaves and fruit.
cure: Use copper sprays during bloom, remove infected shoots, and plant disease-resistant varieties.

name: Peach___healthy
cause: Healthy foliage is free of yellowing or black spots and is firm in texture.
cure: Keep trees well-pruned, avoid overhead irrigation, and use balanced nutrients to ensure vitality.

name: Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot
cause: Bacterium Xanthomonas campestris causes greasy dark lesions on leaves and fruit.
cure: Avoid wetting foliage, use copper-based bactericides, and rotate crops yearly.

name: Pepper,_bell___healthy
cause: Healthy bell pepper leaves are broad, green, and free of spots or curling.
cure: Provide full sunlight, fertilize moderately, and monitor humidity to sustain plant health.

name: Potato___Early_blight
cause: Caused by Alternaria solani. Concentric brown rings appear on older leaves.
cure: Remove infected leaves, rotate with non-host crops, and spray protectant fungicides weekly in season.

name: Potato___Late_blight
cause: Phytophthora infestans causes rapid leaf browning, wilting, and collapse in wet conditions.
cure: Use certified disease-free seed, apply fungicides proactively, and destroy infected plant residues.

name: Potato___healthy
cause: No lesions or yellowing. Leaves are uniform and upright.
cure: Maintain well-drained soil, manage irrigation schedules, and fertilize with nitrogen carefully.

name: Raspberry___healthy
cause: No fungal or viral symptoms present. Foliage is fresh and green.
cure: Mulch properly, prune annually, and inspect leaves to detect early infections.

name: Soybean___healthy
cause: Healthy soybean leaves are bright green and free of discoloration or edge burn.
cure: Inoculate seeds with rhizobia, provide potassium-rich soil, and scout for leaf pests regularly.

name: Squash___Powdery_mildew
cause: Erysiphe cichoracearum causes powdery white growth on leaf surfaces.
cure: Use sulfur sprays early, thin plant spacing, and irrigate at the root level to reduce humidity.

name: Strawberry___Leaf_scorch
cause: Caused by Diplocarpon earlianum. Small purple spots coalesce into scorched margins.
cure: Remove infected leaves, avoid wet foliage, and apply fungicides during flowering stage.

name: Strawberry___healthy
cause: Leaf tissue is bright green with no brown edges or spots.
cure: Avoid overhead watering, mulch with straw, and provide full sunlight to reduce fungal risk.

name: Tomato___Bacterial_spot
cause: Xanthomonas spp. cause water-soaked lesions that enlarge and cause yellowing.
cure: Use copper-based bactericides, rotate crops, and keep foliage dry during irrigation.

name: Tomato___Early_blight
cause: Alternaria solani causes dark spots with concentric rings and yellowing around lesions.
cure: Remove lower infected leaves, apply chlorothalonil fungicide, and avoid wetting leaves.

name: Tomato___Late_blight
cause: Phytophthora infestans causes large water-soaked areas on leaves and stems.
cure: Destroy infected plants, improve drainage, and apply systemic fungicides like mefenoxam.

name: Tomato___Leaf_Mold
cause: Passalora fulva causes yellow patches that turn brown. Common in high humidity.
cure: Improve air circulation, water early in the day, and apply fungicides with copper or mancozeb.

name: Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot
cause: Septoria lycopersici creates tiny brown spots with light centers and dark margins.
cure: Remove infected foliage and apply protective fungicides starting at early fruiting stage.

name: Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider_mite
cause: Tetranychus urticae mites feed on leaves, causing stippling, yellowing, and webbing.
cure: Spray neem oil or insecticidal soap, and increase humidity to reduce mite activity.

name: Tomato___Target_Spot
cause: Corynespora cassiicola causes circular dark spots with yellow halos.
cure: Use resistant cultivars, reduce humidity, and apply chlorothalonil-based fungicides.

name: Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus
cause: Transmitted by whiteflies, causing leaf curling, yellowing, and stunted growth.
cure: Use yellow sticky traps, control whiteflies with soap sprays, and remove infected plants early.

name: Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus
cause: Spread by contaminated tools or contact. Leaves show mottling and distortion.
cure: Disinfect tools regularly, destroy infected plants, and avoid smoking near plants.

name: Tomato___healthy
cause: Foliage is firm, green, and photosynthetically efficient without curling or spots.
cure: Maintain balanced fertilization, adequate spacing, and proper watering to retain leaf vitality.
